page.title: 08The Landscape at Stoulton
page.content:
Farming is mainly arable and most of the land is covered with wheat and barley, but also some oats and peas. A modern innovation is the use of oil seed rape which gives rise to large bright splashes of yellow amongst the more gentle shades of the landscape. Orchards containing plums, damsons, apples and pears still exist but they are declining rapidly as are the soft fruits. Cattle and sheep farming are also present. Most of the cattle is young stock nutured for future dairy herds of which there is only one in the area. There are several farms and all are owner occupied, there are no large estates in the area. There is only one large farm of about 1,000 acres, the rest of the farms are about 250 acres.
.
